## 1. Read in the data
```{r}
met <- read.csv("met_all.gz")
```

## 2. Check the dimensions, headers, footers
```{r}
dim(met)
```
2377343 rows and 30 columns

## 3. Take a look at all the variables (hint: use the str function).
```{r}
str(met)
```

## 4. Take a closer look at the key variables
```{r}
summary(met)
```
```{r}
met$elev[met$elev %in% c(9999)] <- NA
met$temp[met$temp %in% c(-40)] <- NA
met_new <- na.omit(met)
summary(met)
```
```{r}
max(met$elev, na.rm = TRUE)
```
At elevation 4113 is the highest weather station.

```{r}
met_clean <- subset(met, !is.na(temp))
sus <- subset(met_clean, temp == -17.2)
sus
```
It locates at Colorado near Colorado Springs/El Paso County.
